claim: Recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS have been shown to induce significantly higher levels of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against highly conserved regions of HA compared with egg-derived vaccines.
explanation: The figure consists of two panels (A and B) showing the proportion of participants in two age groups (18–44 years and 45–64 years) who had a ≥4-fold reduced hemagglutination inhibition (HI) titer to cell-grown vaccine virus (egg/cell titer ratio) before (Pre) and one month after (Post) repeat influenza vaccination. Data are shown for four influenza strains (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata) across seven different vaccination arms (cell-based IIV4, recombinant RIV4, egg-based IIV4, and combinations thereof, including Fluzone IIV4). Trend lines with p values indicate statistically significant changes in proportions between pre- and post-vaccination. The data shown pertain to changes in HI titers against cell- versus egg-propagated vaccine viruses across vaccine platforms and age groups; they do not provide evidence about recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS or about induction of broadly cross-reactive antibodies to conserved HA regions. Therefore, this figure does not support the claim. Note: Figure is clear but focuses solely on HI titer ratios, not on BEVS-derived antigens or cross-reactive antibody specificity.
